article.name: Enable and Customize PhishER DKIM Signatures
article.title: Enable and Customize PhishER DKIM Signatures
article.body:
PhishER notifications contain a line of text called a DKIM signature that proves it is an authentic KnowBe4 or custom email. This guide will show you how to enable DKIM signatures for PhishER from KnowBe4 and how to use an allowed domain as a custom DKIM signature.

Enabling DKIM Signatures in PhishER

To enable your DKIM Signatures in PhishER, follow the steps below:

  1. Open the PhishER platform and then navigate to the Settings page.
  2. Go to Email Server.
  3. Customize the Email Server settings and enable the DKIM Signature toggle. When you enable the toggle, you will see the Signing Domain(s) and the Selector from your KSAT Account Settings page.

  1. Click Save.

Using Custom DKIM Signatures

After enabling DKIM signatures, your organization can adjust the signing domain for your organization’s needs.

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 account and navigate to PhishER.
  2. Click on the Settings icon and go to Email Server page.
  3. Under the Configure DKIM section, click the button labeled Add Custom Signing Domain.

  1. Choose the domain you wish to use. To add a domain to this drop-down menu, you will first need to add the domain as an Allowed Domain in your KnowBe4 account. See our How to Add and Verify Allowed Domains article for more information.
  2. Click Add and the Configure Custom Signing Domain window will open.
  3. Copy the host name and values provided in the pop-up.

  1. Navigate to your DNS provider and add a TXT record containing the copied information.
Note: To verify that the TXT record has been recognized by your DNS provider, click the Validate the DNS TXT record button.
  1. Once you’ve created the TXT record in your DNS provider, select the domains that you want to use the new DKIM record.
  2. Click Save.

For further assistance with this feature, please contact our support team and they will be happy to help.

images.alt:
This image displays the "Email Server" configuration page within the "SETTINGS" dashboard of a web application. The panel focuses on defining default email identity and DKIM settings.

## UI Elements and Configuration Details

The interface is divided into a left navigation sidebar (where "Email Server" is actively selected under the "ACCOUNT" group) and a main configuration pane.

### Email Server Settings

The main pane presents the following configuration fields, most of which are text input fields or checkboxes:

1.  **Default From Address (a):** Input field, pre-filled with `no-reply@phisher.knowbe4.com`.
2.  **Default From Name (b):** Empty input field.
3.  **Default Reply to Address (c):** Input field, pre-filled with `no-reply@phisher.knowbe4.com`.
4.  **Default Reply to Name (d):** Empty input field.
5.  **X-Phisher header (e):** Empty input field.
6.  **Email Headers (f):** Checkbox labeled "Overwrite Fixed Return-path Address with From Address" (Checked).

### DKIM Configuration

This section manages domain key identified mail (DKIM) settings:

1.  **DKIM Signature (g):** Checkbox labeled "Enable" (Checked).
2.  **Configure DKIM (h):** Radio button selection is active for "Use Your Signing Domain." The alternate option, "Use KnowBe4's Signing Domain," is unselected.
    *   Labels for "Signing Domain" and "Selector" are visible beneath the radio buttons.
3.  **Action Buttons (i):** An orange button labeled "Add Custom Signing Domain" is visible, adjacent to a circular information icon.
4.  **Save Button (j):** A primary orange button labeled "Save" is located at the bottom of the main configuration area.

### Allowed Domains (k)

A secondary panel, titled "Allowed Domains," lists three approved domains:
*   `kb4u-demo.com`
*   `knowbe4.com`
*   `kb4-tutorials.com`

A footer note explains the purpose of the list: "Allowed Domains can be used to send custom emails to the users in that domain. To update the allowed domains, visit the KMSAT **Settings page**" (with "Settings page" displayed as a hyperlink).

images.alt:
This image displays a User Interface (UI) modal window titled **"Add Custom Signing Domain"** in bold, large text.

The primary content area below the title contains the following elements:
1.  **Instructional Text:** "Select the signing domain for this DNS record:"
2.  **Input Element:** A dropdown selection field labeled **"Select Signing Domain"** with a downward chevron icon, indicating it is currently awaiting user input.

The bottom section of the modal contains two action buttons:
1.  **Secondary Action Button:** A button labeled **"Cancel"** (white background, black text), typically used to close the modal without making changes.
2.  **Primary Action Button:** A button labeled **"Add"** (orange/red background, white text), which is the principal action button for submitting the form.

images.alt:
This image displays a configuration modal titled **"Configure Custom Signing Domain"**, focused on DNS and DKIM record setup.

**UI Elements and Context:**

1.  **Signing Domain Selection:** A field labeled **"Select the signing domain for this DNS record:"** contains a dropdown displaying the selected domain: `knowbe4.com`.
2.  **TXT Record Generation:** Two fields present the necessary DNS TXT record data (obscured/censored):
    *   **"The HOST NAME for your TXT record:"** (A populated, read-only field).
    *   **"The value for your TXT record:"** (A populated, read-only multiline text area).
    *   An action button, **"Validate the DNS TXT record"** (Orange), is positioned below the TXT value field.
3.  **DKIM Domain Assignment:** A section labeled **"Select the domains that will use this DKIM record:"** presents a list of domains with corresponding checkboxes.
    *   The list includes seven domains, such as `elephantsrock.com`, `myexampledomain.com`, and `ztest.professorphisher.com`.
    *   The domain `knowbe4.com` is currently checked/selected.
4.  **Action Buttons:** The footer contains two primary action buttons: **"Cancel"** (Standard) and **"Save"** (Primary, Orange).
